Futures for the S&P 500 index, Nasdaq 100 and Dow Jones industrial average rose early Wednesday ahead of Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's testimony to Congress on Wednesday and Thursday. Investors will be looking for more hints about when the Fed will start whittling down its massive $4.5 trillion balance sheet.On Tuesday, the Nasdaq composite rose 0.3%, the Dow closed flat and the S&P 500 fell 0.1%. Three chip plays are now close to buy points: Apple (AAPL)-supplier Broadcom (AVGO) and chip-equipment makers Applied Materials (AMAT) and ASML Holding (ASML).XIt's important to see these chip stocks faring well. All three are highly rated, and if the market is going to find its footing and go much higher it will need top stocks to lead. Chip stocks overall were among the biggest losers in the recent tech selloff, so it's good to see them bounce back. That's especially true because chips are in the guts of just about tech product, from the Apple iPhone, data centers, auto electronics and just about everything else. If chips are doing well, that's a good sign for end products.Several other chip stocks are acting constructively, including Nvidia (NVDA) and Lam Research (LRCX). Nvidia never even fell below its 50-day line, but both Nvidia and Lam Research need to consolidate longer to form proper consolidations after their relatively large sell-offs in June.Futures for the S&P 500 rose 0.3% vs. fair value. The Dow industrials climbed 0.2%. Futures for the Nasdaq 100 climbed 0.5% vs. fair value.In Asian trading, Japan's Nikkei slid 0.5% and China's Shanghai composite 0.2%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed 0.6%. In European trading intraday, the U.K.'s FTSE rose 0.9%, Germany's Dax 0.7% and France's CAC-40 0.9%.The Apple supplier was one of the better-performing chip stocks from the June 9 tech reversal. Shares fell sharply on June 9, but Broadcom held its ground for the next few weeks. Finally on June 29, the company fell below its 50-day moving average. It retook that level on July 7 and has found support at that line, though the recent rebound hasn't been on strong volume. Broadcom is now in a flat base like many other stocks, including Apple, ASML and Applied Materials.Shares dipped 0.4% to 240.89 in Tuesday stock market trading, about 6% below a 256.88 buy point.(Apple for its part rose 0.3% to 145.53 but is still below its 50-day moving average, which is now leveling off. Apple is about 7% off a potential 156.75 entry.)Broadcom has a Composite Rating of 96, which means that the stock outperforms 96% of all stocks based on a variety of fundamental and technical factors. Big stock winners through history have often had a Composite Rating of 95+ near the start of their big price moves.ASML Holding is in a flat base going back to May 16, with a possible entry at 137.37. The Dutch maker of lithography systems tumbled below its 50-day line on June 9, where it largely stayed through July 6. But on July 7 shares just retook that support area. ASML continued to climb, including a 0.75% rise to 135.82 on Tuesday.ASML will report second-quarter results on Wednesday, July 19, before the market open.ASML has a Composite Rating of 96.Applied Materials, another big maker of chip equipment, rose 2.7% to 45.40 on Tuesday. Applied Materials climbed 1.5% on Monday, retaking its 50-day moving average after advancing 3.4% on Friday.Applied Materials is about 5% off a flat-base consolidation buy point of 47.96.Applied Materials has a best-possible 99 CR.RELATED:Chip Stock Upgraded To Buy On Apple, Tesla Contract WinsApple iPhone 8 Expectations Too High, No 'Supercycle' Ahead: AnalystStocks Shake Off Trump Emails; These Key Events Could Move MarketYellen May Trigger Stocks, Banks; Amazon Reviews: Investing Action Plan

Tech stocks continued to lead the U.S. market higher Monday. Apple (AAPL), meanwhile, showed potential of recouping some of the nearly 9% decline suffered over the prior two weeks and continuing its solid uptrend since its January breakout past an early-stage cup-with-handle base at 118.12.The stock rebounded 4.12, or 2.9%, to 146.39 in volume that edged 2% above normal levels. Apple is also up 26% since Jan. 1, more than double the 9.5% gain for the S&P 500. Both the 500 (up 0.8%) and the Dow Jones industrials (up 0.7%) hit all-time new highs in the stock market today.But at the market's close at 4 p.m. ET, the Nasdaq composite reaffirmed its market leadership, stretching its gain to 1.4% and holding practically at session highs, and extending its year-to-date gain to 15.9%.Small caps lagged, as the S&P SmallCap 600 rose just 0.5%.In the Dow 30 industrials, as many as nine members are up one point or more, including top-tier banks JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS). Reuters reported an estimate by a Morgan Stanley analyst that the main banks have as much as $150 billion in idle cash that could be funneled toward future dividend hikes and share buybacks.The Federal Reserve is set to release initial results on Thursday of a two-part annual stress test of major Wall Street banks. The stress test, created in the wake of the 2008-2009 subprime debt debacle, offers investors the central U.S. bank's view of how the nation's biggest lenders would handle a future economic or financial shock that could rattle the banking system.IBD analyzes the market action based on the movement of 197 industry groups and subgroups each day. Among the top 10 performers on Monday, six six hailed from the medical, computer and electronics sectors, including biotechs, generic drugs, integrated computer systems, computer networking and fabless semiconductors. You can check the individual stocks and ratings for all of these industry groups by going to MarketSmith, IBD's premium stock screening and charting service.Integrated oil, water utility, oil drilling and gas distribution companies led the market's downside, falling 0.9% or more. WTI crude oil futures slid 1.2% to $44.20 a barrel, while NYMEX natural gas futures collapsed more than 4% to $2.89 per 1 million BTUs, a new 3-month low. The Dow utility average slipped 0.4%. Long-term interest rates edged up, with the yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury benchmark bond rising to 2.19%.Market breadth is positive, with winners beating losers by a nearly 9-5 ratio on the Nasdaq and an 18-11 ratio on the NYSE. Volume was down sharply on the main exchanges vs. the same time Friday. Stock and index options expired Friday, resulting in higher volume. This column last week noted that Apple posted a pair of sell signals for short-term investors: 1) dropping sharply below its 10-week moving average in accelerating volume; and 2) giving back all of its gains from a four-weeks-tight entry at 141.12. But the iPhone maker could also have been held by longtime holders who have a big enough profit cushion to give the stock a chance to rise back above the 10-week line or possibly test the longer-term 40-week moving average, roughly equivalent to the 200-day moving average on a daily chart.Apple is now less than three points away from retaking the 10-week line.Another fellow tech component in the Dow 30, Microsoft (MSFT) is holding up firmly since it broke out of a base-on-base setup at 58.80 in the week ended Oct. 21, 2016. The Xbox and business software firm, up 1% to 70.87, has gained nearly 24% since that October breakout. The S&P 500 has risen 14% over the same time frame. Both Apple and Microsoft pay dividends, and the annualized yields are 1.8% and 2.2%, respectively. The S&P 500 has a 1.91% yield. Microsoft's long-term cash payout growth is 15% each year, according to calculations by William O'Neil + Co.An ongoing rebound in fundamentals for both Apple and Microsoft, plus the outperformance of the tech sector in 2017 so far, are two reasons why the two megacap names have good prospects for beating the S&P 500's return this year.Among the top five sectors in IBD's daily ranking of 33 broad sectors, three of the top five are from tech land: Electronics (No. 1), Chips (No. 2), and Computer (No. 4). The other two in the top five are Leisure (No. 3) and Building (No. 5).IBD's TAKE: Apple, due to the majority of its revenue now coming from the iPhone, is part of the Telecom sector, which is now ranked No. 14 out of 33 broad industry sectors. A strong sector performance often helps a growth stock achieve above-average returns. See the entire list of sectors, ranked daily, via the Stock Lists section at Investors.com.As seen in IBD Stock Checkup, Microsoft ranks No. 3 within the desktop software industry group in terms of its 82 Composite Rating. It trails group leader Adobe Systems (ADBE) (96 Composite) and Red Hat (RHT) (92). However, Microsoft has successfully turned around its recent slump in revenue with gains of 1% and 8% vs. year-ago levels in the prior two quarters. Microsoft had suffered a six-quarter drought of flat or falling sales.Microsoft also sports a top-notch A rating for SMR (Sales + Profit Margins + Return on equity).Elsewhere in the stock market today, MasTec (MTZ) rallied more than 2% to 45.60 in quiet trade. Read more about the base this building and maintenance services firm is forming in IBD's Stocks Near A Buy Zone feature, available in the Stock Lists section at Investors.com.Broadcom (AVGO) rallied more than 2% to 241.15 in slightly above-average turnover; the top-quality semiconductor stock is once again extended a little more than 5% past a 227.85 flat-base entry. Lam Research (LRCX), a former Big Cap 20 member, hopped off its 50-day line, rising almost 2% to 150.97. Volume ran up 24% higher than the stock's 50-day average of 2.24 million shares.As noted in the latest IBD Weekly print edition, last week's negative reversal in heavy volume marked a sell signal following the chip equipment firm's outstanding run.Yet for now, the stock is getting vital buying support at the 50-day moving average, a key trait among leading growth stocks.Lam is No. 5 in the IBD 50. The Street expects earnings to rise 57% to $9.88 a share in fiscal 2017 ending in June; but growth is expected to slow to 10% in FY 2018. Keep in mind, however, that Lam has beaten the consensus profit estimate by nearly 6% on average over the past four quarters.Some consumer spending plays are also thriving; please check IBD Weekly in pages B1 to B4 and see the chart analysis for every minichart of the IBD 50. From April 11, 2003 to Dec. 31, 2016, the total return of the IBD 50 is 750%, vs. a 242% gain for the S&P 500 (excluding dividends).RELATED:Inside The IBD 50: So, How Much Further Can The Leaders FallHow Should I Track The Market: The Big Picture Can HelpWhat's The Simplest Way To Spot Major Market Tops?

The semiconductor capital equipment sector has been on fire lately as chip and display manufacturers upgrade their factories to make the latest technologies.IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group now ranks No. 5 out of 197 industry groups in terms of stock market performance. Investment bank Morgan Stanley on Thursday selected nine "high conviction" stocks that have near-term catalysts that could move their shares higher.Of the nine, four are technology stocks: Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Amazon.com (AMZN), IBM (IBM) and Lam Research (LRCX). And a fifth, Align Technology (ALGN), is a medical-products (teeth alignment) company.Two of the companies are currently featured on the IBD 50 list of superior stocks: Activision and Align. And one, Amazon, is on IBD's Leaderboard list.The others are wireless tower operator Crown Castle (CCI), commercial bank SVB Financial Group (SIVB), and energy services firms Helix Energy Solutions (HLX) and Parsley Energy (PE).IBD'S TAKE: Investors.com offers a host of proprietary stock lists to give investors actionable ideas about companies worth considering. The IBD 50 is IBD's flagship screen of leading growth stocks showing strong relative price strength and top-notch fundamentals. Leaderboard provides a select group of stock picks showing the most potential for big gains."Our analysts believe that one or more imminent events will drive the share price (of the nine stocks) materially over the next 15-60 days," a group of Morgan Stanley analysts said in a research report.Morgan Stanley analyst Brian Nowak expects video game publisher Activision to beat Wall Street's estimates when it reports third-quarter earnings on Nov. 3. The Santa Monica, Calif.-based company is benefiting from a shift to higher-margin game downloads, vs. packaged media sales, and online and mobile-game traction, he said.Potential catalysts include a faster-than-anticipated shift to full-game downloads and indications that Activision is monetizing its King Digital user base through advertising."Currently 15% to 20% of games are downloaded digitally, and we expect this to increase to 40%-plus in the next five years," Nowak said.Align Technology, which makes teeth-straightening systems, is set to report its Q3 earnings on Nov. 7.Morgan Stanley analyst Steve Beuchaw is looking for San Jose, Calif.-based Align to report strong results. Catalysts for the stock include inflections in discretionary spending, the rollout of Align's G6 feature set, and collaboration with more digital scanner partners.E-commerce leader Amazon is likely to report its Q3 results in late October. Nowak is expecting Amazon to beat Wall Street's consensus expectations."Our estimates are driven by higher gross profit per customer, which more than offsets our expectations for higher forward streaming-content (spending) and increased fulfillment deleverage from Amazon's large expected warehouse build this year," Nowak said. "We also see potential for further upside due to ongoing strength in Amazon's AWS cloud-computing business."Amazon is moving into a phase of improving profitability in its core e-commerce business, even as it takes market share, he said.Potential catalysts include Amazon's Q3 results, acceleration of e-commerce penetration in core markets, Prime membership growth, and enterprise cloud adoption hitting an inflection point, Nowak said.Tech services giant IBM could see a lift as it makes progress transitioning from mainframe and other legacy businesses, Morgan Stanley analyst Katy Huberty said. IBM is becoming more exposed to its emerging businesses in Watson, cloud, analytics, mobile and security, which have double-digit growth profiles, she said.IBM's potential catalysts include an accelerated transformation and recent acquisitions helping to achieve a faster path to revenue growth and improving profit margins, she said.Semiconductor equipment maker Lam Research is set to report its September quarter results on Oct. 19 and will hold an analyst meeting on Nov. 16."We would expect both events to be positive for the stock," Morgan Stanley analyst Joe Moore said. Investors are likely to take a fresh look at Lam in the wake of its failed merger with inspection equipment vendor KLA-Tencor (KLAC).

Investment bank Citigroup on Wednesday upgraded two chip-equipment manufacturers to buy, while Pacific Crest Securities downgraded two others.Citigroup upgraded Brooks Automation (BRKS) to buy from neutral and initiated coverage of MKS Instruments (MKSI) with a buy rating.Pacific Crest downgraded Lam Research (LRCX) and Nanometrics (NANO) to sector weight from overweight.IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group ranks No. 24 out of 197 groups. Check out the largest company in the sector, Applied Materials, on the IBD 50 list of top-performing stocks over the past 52-weeks."We anticipate order declines and limited demand growth for semiconductor equipment names as 3D Nand equipment demand is likely to peak in 2017, while logic/foundry demand remains mixed and DRAM demand remains low," Pacific Crest analyst Weston Twigg said in a research report late Tuesday. "Sector valuations are reasonable, so we do not see meaningful near-term downside risk, but further stock appreciation may be limited."He reiterated his overweight ratings on Applied Materials (AMAT), MKS and Entegris (ENTG) for longer-term opportunities."We remain Overweight on AMAT due to good long-term positioning, MKSI due to strong earnings leverage and non-semiconductor growth opportunities, and ENTG due to its unique position to benefit from slowing node transitions," Twigg said. "We are downgrading LRCX and NANO to Sector Weight, both of which are near our price targets and may stall if 3D Nand spending peaks in 2017."Lam Research stock rallied after its planned merger with KLA-Tencor (KLAC) fell apart on Oct. 5 because of antitrust objections.Twigg says chip-gear orders peaked for the current capital-equipment investment cycle in June. He is forecasting 1% semiconductor capital-expenditure growth in 2017, vs. consensus views for 4% to 7% growth.Shares of Brooks Automation closed up 2.2% to 13.55 on the stock market today. MKS Instruments rallied 1.5% to 48.69, Lam Research dipped 0.9% to 98.68, and Nanometrics gapped down 5.2% to 20.28.RELATED:Applied Materials Makes 'Compelling Case' For Growth In Chip-Gear Sector

A handful of leading stocks broke out to new highs or followed through on recent breakouts in the stock market today despite a narrowly mixed performance by the major market indexes.Lam Research (LRCX) gapped up and surged 4% Thursday, following through on its Wednesday breakout past a 95.87 flat-base buy point. Volume on Wednesday was 42% above average -- on Thursday, it swelled to 355% higher-than-normal trade.Investors were clearly not worried about the chip gear maker's breakup with KLA-Tencor (KLAC). Late Wednesday, the two companies dumped their planned $11 billion merger deal, citing antitrust concerns. Intel (INTC), Hitachi and Samsung were reportedly among companies opposing the potential union."We believe that this proposed combination would have resulted in compelling benefits for our customers, employees and stockholders, as well as accelerate innovation in the broader semiconductor industry, so we are disappointed with the outcome," Lam CEO Martin Anstice said in a press release.Central Garden & Pet (CENTA) climbed past a 25.88 buy point intraday Thursday, but closed just below the entry. Volume was well below normal. The lawn and garden products maker marked a record high during the session.Cinemark Holdings (CNK) rose 2% to a 52-week high, clearing a 39.55 flat-base buy point in heavier-than-usual trade. The Plano, Texas-based company operates theaters in 41 U.S. states and in Latin American countries.ICU Medical (ICUI) vaulted 15% to a new high, breaking out past a 129.02 buy point in massive volume.  The stock is a bit thinly traded with an average daily volume of about 95,000 shares. The San Clemente, Calif.-based medical products maker is buying Pfizer's (PFE) infusion systems unit for $1 billion in cash and stock.RELATED:Lam Research, KLA-Tencor Scrap Chip Gear Deal On Antitrust Concerns

Citing "recent antitrust agency feedback," chip gear giants Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor (KLAC) late Wednesday scrapped their planned $11 billion merger agreement."We believe that this proposed combination would have resulted in compelling benefits for our customers, employees and stockholders, as well as accelerate innovation in the broader semiconductor industry, so we are disappointed with the outcome," said Lam Research CEO Martin Anstice.Antitrust concerns had been swirling for months, with the two companies announcing in August that they wouldn't meet a planned October closing date. Intel reportedly objected to the Lam-KLA deal, along with Samsung and Hitachi. Intel (INTC) generally opposes key suppliers merging. Chip gear rival Applied Materials (AMAT), which saw its Tokyo Electron merger deal founder on Justice Department objections last year, also likely is happy to see the deal called off.IBD'S TAKE: While Twitter is also on the block, Facebook continues to grow rapidly. Facebook's stock hovers near a buy point.KLA-Tencor raised its quarterly dividend to 54 cents a share from 52 cents.Lam Research and KLA-Tencor fell modestly late Wednesday, following the 6 p.m. ET announcement. But by Thursday's premarket, Lam Research rose 3.4% after hitting an all-time high on Wednesday, ending Thursday up 4.2%, at 100.19.KLA-Tencor rose 1.3% before the opening bell on the stock market today, ending the day up a fraction, at 71.79. On Wednesday, KLA-Tencor rose 1.3% to 71.21, retaking its 200-day and 50-day line.RELATED:Applied Materials Makes 'Compelling Case' For Growth In Chip Gear SectorGoogle, Apple Seen As Unlikely To Bid For Twitter

Stocks ended narrowly mixed Thursday and well off their session lows, despite big drops by some high-profile names, including American Express (AXP), Tesla (TSLA) and Twitter (TWTR).The S&P 500 eked out a less than 0.1% gain, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1% and the Nasdaq gave up 0.2%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. Wednesday, according to preliminary figures.Retailers, chip gear makers and building-related stocks led the upside in the stock market today, while gold miners, carmakers and medical stocks lagged. West Texas intermediate crude prices added 1.4% to $50.52 a barrel; gold futures fell 1% to $1,256.40 an ounce.Lam Research (LRCX) gapped up and leapt 4% to a new high in heavy trade, following through on a Wednesday breakout past a 95.87 flat-base buy point. On the downside, American Express was the biggest Dow loser, with a 4% drop in twice normal trade. The stock breached its 200-day moving average for the first time in two months. Chip gear maker Applied Materials (AMAT) saw its stock hit a 16-year high Thursday following positive response to the company's analyst day presentations.Applied Materials stock climbed intraday as high as a 16-year-best 31.06 on the stock market today. But the stock closed down 0.9% at 30.28. Applied Materials reached its all-time high of 57.50 in April 2000 at the peak of the dot-com boom.Pacific Crest Securities analyst Weston Twigg said Applied offered a "compelling case for growth" at its analyst event. He reiterated his overweight rating on the stock and raised his price target to 35 from 33.IBD'S TAKE: Applied Materials is No. 1 in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Equipment industry group and sports a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. It also is on the IBD 50 list of superior stocks."We remain positive on AMAT, which should continue to gain share and expand its served markets as its product development engine keeps producing hits," Twigg said in a research report Wednesday. "We believe that AMAT is the best-positioned equipment company over the next three years in both semiconductors and display."Credit Suisse analyst Farhan Ahmad said Applied Materials set conservative targets, especially in wafer fab equipment, at its analyst day. But rivals Lam Research (LRCX) and TE Connectivity (TEL) are targeting similar opportunities, such as in patterning and 3D Nand chip equipment, he said.Ahmad reiterated his outperform rating on Applied Materials stock, with a price target of 34.Applied Materials sees long-term opportunities in OLED display manufacturing, fueled by smartphones, VR headsets and televisions; and chips for augmented reality hardware and smart vehicles.Applied's analyst event in New York City highlighted the company's momentum with sustainable growth, Needham analyst Edwin Mok said in a report. He reiterated his buy rating on AMAT with a price target of 34."We saw the presentation as a 'victory lap' after several years of management's efforts to reposition AMAT's strategy and operating model to drive share gains in multiple areas and (market) expansions," Mok said.
