Altera (ALTR) stock hit a fresh 15-year high Monday after the Chinese Ministry of Commerce approved its acquisition by No. 1 chipmaker Intel (INTC) — the final regulatory obstacle to the transaction. The $16.7 billion acquisition, at about $54 a share, is expected to close Dec. 28, according to 8K filings with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. In morning…

Nomura Securities stuck its neck out on Wednesday and revealed its top stock picks for 2016 in technology, media and telecom. Analysts for the investment bank picked five stocks as "top picks for 2016": Alphabet (GOOGL), Arista Networks (ANET), Lam Research (LRCX), LinkedIn (LNKD) and Microsoft (MSFT). It rates all five stocks as buy.Alphabet and LinkedIn are IBD Leaderboard stocks, while the others are also highly ranked by IBD with Composite Ratings of at least 89 out of a possible 99.Google parent Alphabet will see mobile search, YouTube and advertising technology as revenue drivers next year, Nomura said. Operating expense discipline and share buybacks should boost earnings per share, analysts said. Nomura raised its price target on Alphabet to 900 from 875. Alphabet stock fell 1.6% to 762.55 on the stock market today.Arista's 50% exposure to cloud computing providers leaves it best positioned to benefit from public cloud adoption, Nomura said. It has a price target on Arista of 95. On Wednesday, Arista dropped 1.9% to 71.84.Chip gear maker Lam Research will see its "transformative merger" with KLA-Tencor (KLAC) boost its valuation and earnings next year, Nomura predicted. Nomura has a price target on Lam of 100. Lam stock dropped 2.6% to 78.32 on Wednesday.LinkedIn's strong product roadmap, including a new mobile app, refreshed Recruiter product, mobile ads, and Lynda.com should drive greater than 25% revenue growth over the next three years, Nomura said. Nomura has a price target on LinkedIn of 290. LinkedIn stock fell 3% to 231.34 on Wednesday.Microsoft should benefit from its transition to cloud computing — such as Office 365, moderating the declines in its Windows operating system business — and from operating expense control, Nomura said. The investment bank raised its price target on Microsoft stock to 65 from 60. Microsoft shares dipped 1.5% to 54.98 on Wednesday.

Apple's (AAPL) iPhone "elephant in the room" clouded Qorvo's (QRVO) otherwise upbeat analyst day, an MKM analyst wrote late Tuesday as he suggested that the chipmaker might be considering a hefty M&A play.Qorvo stock closed up 5.6% in the stock market today at 54.74.March-quarter expectations for a 10%-15% depression in iPhone sales remained unchanged, MKM analyst Ian Ing noted in a research report. Ing retired his 71 price target and buy rating on Qorvo stock."With the iPhone 'elephant in the room,' we felt investor concerns regarding a smartphone unit slowdown remained only partially addressed and not in Qorvo's control," Ing wrote.Slower growth rates are still likely out of China, he added.But Qorvo's overall outlook was positive, Ing wrote. The company revised its long-term target model to 32%-35% vs. an earlier 30% target and outlined plans to recapture Samsung and MediaTek smartphone share in China.A recent $1 billion debt issuance could signal that Qorvo's Industrial and Defense Products segment is becoming acquisitive, Ing wrote. Strategic M&A could help Qorvo's IDP business grow at twice the industry's 7% growth rate.Qorvo would merely be the latest in a series of recently acquisitive chip companies. Last month, Lam Research (LRCX) agreed to acquire KLA-Tencor (KLAC), a combination that might overtake Applied Materials' (AMAT) market share, and Western Digital (WDC) made a bid for SanDisk (SNDK).Earlier this year, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR), and Avago Technologies (AVGO) announced its plan to acquire Broadcom (BRCM).Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

Apple (AAPL) supplier NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) muscled by completing its $12 billion acquisition of smaller peer Freescale Semiconductor, making it No. 5 by market value in IBD's 46-company Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group.
With a $20.4 billion market cap, NXP trails only Qualcomm (QCOM), Avago Technologies (AVGO), Broadcom (BRCM) — all fellow Apple suppliers — and ARM Holdings (ARMH) .

In late-afternoon trading on the stock market today, NXP stock was up nearly 2%, near 88. Freescale stock closed down 1.5%, at 36.53, on Monday, its last day of trading on the NYSE. NXP stock fell 4.6% on Monday.
The companies announced the closing of their deal on Monday. The merger was announced in March, heralding a record-busting year for chip industry M&As.
In May, Avago agreed to buy Broadcom for $37 billion. A month later, Intel (INTC) announced that it had inked a $16.7 billion deal to buy Altera (ALTR) .
On a single day in October, Western Digital (WDC) agreed to buy SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion, and chip gear maker Lam Research (LRCX) put up a $10.6 billion bid for rival KLA-Tencor (KLAC).

Last month, On Semiconductor (ON) agreed to buy Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) for $2.4 billion. Meanwhile, Microsemi (MSCC) and Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) battled it out for PMC-Sierra (PMCS) for over a month before Microsemi won with a $2.5 billion offer.
Combined, NXP and Freescale expect $10 billion in annual sales. The merged company has 45,000 employees — including 11,000 engineers — and 9,000 patent families, according to an NXP overview.
NXP says that it expects to be No. 1 in communications processors, secure identification, broad-based microcontrollers, radio-frequency transistors, automotive chips and small-signal discretes.
In 2020, NXP aims to ship 40 billion connected devices in areas such as secure ID and mobile transactions.

Together, NXP and Freescale plan to lead the industry in chips for payment cards, point-of-sale terminals, transport ticketing, closed loop payment and mobile transactions, according to the company's plan.

Today, "90% of auto innovation" is within electronics, according to NXP. The company says that it plans to lead the industry in terms of infotainment, vehicle networking, body, safety and secure access.

Amid slowing growth in smartphone sales, ARM Holdings is going to great lengths to tap new markets. The Cambridge, England-based chip designer is hiring hundreds of R&D engineers and acquiring companies and patents to develop next-generation technology. Through the first three quarters of the year, ARM (ARMH) has hired 559 employees, on top of the 441 it put on the…

Lam Research (LRCX) and KLA-Tencor's (KLAC) impending marriage left little "attractive or sizable" in the dating ring for Applied Materials (AMAT), one analyst suggested late Thursday after the No. 1 chip gear-maker reported mixed Q4 earnings.
But, investor relief led Applied Materials stock to jump Friday. In midday trading on the stock market today, shares were up 5% near 17.50.

For its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 25, Applied Materials reported $2.37 billion in sales and 29 cents earnings per share ex items. The consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters saw slightly higher revenue, $2.4 billion, while EPS met their expectations.

Applied Materials guided Q1 sales down 2%-9% sequentially, implying revenue of $2.24 billion at the midpoint of guidance vs. the consensus forecast for $2.27 billion and year-ago revenue of $2.36 billion.
The company also sees 23-27 cents EPS ex items. A year earlier, EPS came in at 27 cents. For the current quarter, Wall Street has been expecting 25 cents.
'Bad But Not Horrible'

Fiscal Q4 was "bad but not horrible," Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire wrote in a research report. (Semiconductor Advisors is a financial and strategic advisory firm to semiconductor and clean-tech industries. In his former capacity as a Morgan Stanley analyst, Maire helped raise $1 billion for Applied Materials and $800 million for KLA-Tencor.)
Applied Materials stock closed down 1.6% Thursday, but rose in after-hours trading.
"The Street was clearly braced for the storm that didn't happen as there was a bit of a relief rally after hours when it turned out that the report, while bad, was not a disaster," Maire wrote.

Late Thursday, Applied Materials reversed year-earlier guidance for a 5%-10% jump in fiscal 2015 sales, saying 2015 would be flat vs. 2014. Fiscal 2016 will be flat with heavier sales in the second half.
Maire wondered where Applied Materials would see growth.

"Applied Materials keeps talking about share gains and organic growth, but we don't see it as being enough to a move a needle as heavy as Applied Materials," he wrote. "We really need some 'shot in the arm' good, old-fashioned inorganic growth to get things going again."
Dickerson Dodges M&A Speculation
It's unlikely M&A action will stoke that growth, he wrote. CEO Gary Dickerson dodged M&A speculation during the Thursday conference call with analysts.
"We're very selective in the opportunities that we look for," he said. The company looks for financial return, strategic alignment and leadership. "The hurdle for us is very high," he added.
Maire theorized Applied Materials must be looking "harder than ever given the Lam-KLA announcement. The problem is that there's just not a lot left that's all that attractive or sizable."
Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan suggested Applied Materials consider a break-up. A hypothetical break-up in 2011 resulted in a higher value than then-stock price, he wrote in a report.
Focus On 3D Nand

Meanwhile, Q1 orders are shaping up well, he wrote. In 2016, 80% of spending will be focused on 3D Nand (flash memory), Dickerson told analysts Thursday. That compares with a 90% estimate at Lam Research, Credit Suisse analyst Farhan Ahmad noted in a separate report.
DRAM (dynamic random-access memory) spending, on the other hand, will be "down significantly," Dickerson said. DRAM bit demand is expected to be 25%-30%.
Applied Materials also guided current-quarter operational expenses up to $550 million vs. $544 million in fiscal Q4. But, a decline in calendar 2016 opex could add 3 cents to EPS, Ahmad wrote.
Continuing aggressive share buybacks could add 21 cents to fiscal 2016 EPS, he added. Over the course of two quarters, Applied Materials bought back $1.3 billion in shares (6% of its market cap).
Sundararajan rates Applied Materials stock a hold and issued a price target of 18. Ahmad boosted his price target on Applied Materials stock to 22.50 from 22 and rates it an outperform.

Applied Materials (AMAT) stock reversed a down-day Thursday on Wall Street after reporting fiscal Q4 sales that topped analyst projections.
In early after-hours trading, Applied Materials stock was up 3.5%. Shares closed down 1.5% in regular-session trading ahead of the No. 1 chip gear-maker's scheduled quarterly earnings report.
For its fiscal Q4 ended Oct. 25, Applied Materials reported 29 cents earnings per share ex items on $2.37 billion in sales, both measures up 7% vs. the year-earlier quarter.

Sales topped the consensus of 21 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $2.4 billion. Applied Materials' 29-cent EPS met the consensus and was the company's second-highest earning quarter behind Q3.
Three months ago, Applied Materials guided to a 7%-to-flat decline in sales vs. Q3 sales of $2.5 billion. The company also saw 27-31 cents EPS minus items.
Fiscal 2015 sales of $9.7 billion, up 6% year over year, and $1.19 EPS ex items, up 11% vs. the year-ago quarter, also narrowly beat the consensus — which saw $9.6 billion and $1.18.
For the current quarter, Applied Materials sees revenue falling 2-9% sequentially and 23-27 cents EPS. In the year-ago quarter, the company reported 23 cents EPS on $2.2 billion in sales.

Applied Materials is in IBD's 36-member Electronic-Semiconductor Equipment industry group. The company has a middling Composite Rating of 49 out of a best-possible 99. Lam Research (LRCX) tops the group with a CR of 91.

Lam might also swipe Applied Materials' No. 1 slot in the chip gear-making sector with the recently announced acquisition of KLA-Tencor (KLAC) (CR of 85), Semiconductor Advisors analyst Robert Maire theorized in a recent research report.
Or, Applied Materials could make a play for KLA by topping Lam's $10.6 billion bid.
"We have to admit that our first reaction to the announcement of the Applied Materials/Tokyo Electron deal was shock that Applied Materials didn't make a play for KLA first," Maire wrote.
The Tokyo Electron deal floundered for nearly two years before it died in the water.

Lam and KLA announced their merger as Western Digital (WDC) confirmed rumors by making a $19 billion play for SanDisk (SNDK), beating out potential interest from Micron Technology (MU) and Seagate Technology (STX) amid mass chip sector consolidation.
KLA's process control operations are superior to Applied Materials' operations, Maire wrote.

"It's more synergistic and, perhaps more importantly, blocks Lam or ASML Holding (ASML) from getting their hands on this crown jewel in the industry," he wrote. "Bottom line, KLA is worth jumping through hoops for."

Meanwhile, a Semiconductor Advisors analyst suggested that Teradyne (TER) could be the next chip equipment company swallowed amid rampant semiconductor M&A action. On Semiconductor put up a $2.4 billion bid for Fairchild Semiconductor, announced early Wednesday. On Semiconductor stock fell 7.9% in the stock market today on the news, while…

Merger buzz in the semiconductor chip industry might have investors in semiconductor ETFs asking: What's in it for me? A whole lot, say experts. And it's generally a whole lotta good. With top-line growth scarce, chipmakers are finding that volume and scale line the path to higher profits. That's creating the perfect space for mergers and acquisitions, says Angelo Zino,…

Leading indexes turned Wednesday's modest opening gains to mixed and busy action, powered primarily by quarterly reports and company news. The Nasdaq backed out of a narrow advance and slipped 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each clung to fractional gains.
Volume swept up 30% on the Nasdaq and rose 5% on the NYSE, gauged against trade at the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today had its little drama sketched out as the Nasdaq rose to test resistance at its 200-day moving average, near the 4800 level.
In stocks,Boeing (BA) and Walt Disney (DIS) led the Dow, up more than 1% apiece. Exotic car maker Ferrari (RACE) throttled up 6% in its first day of trade.

But KLA-Tencor (KLAC) was the stock to catch on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq 100, up 24% at the open after reporting Q3 results and announcing it would be bought by Lam Research (LRCX) in a cash/stock deal valued at $10.6 billion. Lam's shares shook off premarket declines and soared 7%.

Chip news wasn't all good, however. Micron Technology (MU) dived 7% after a downgrade to underperform from Bank of America. Micron fell 115 Tuesday on word that SanDisk (SNDK) was in late-stage merger talks with Western Digital (WDC), dimming hopes for a chip wedding between SanDisk and Micron.
Biogen (BIIB) gabbed a 6% gain after reporting an across-the-board Q3 win. The stock has been feeling for a bottom in a deep double dip, seven-month consolidation.
Manhattan Associates (MANH) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) bracketed the IBD 50 list.
Manhattan surged 4% on a solid third-quarter report . The jump snatched back Tuesday's loss and sent shares 6% above 65.63 cup-with-handle buy point.
Chipotle slumped 7% after reporting disappointing Q3 results late Tuesday. The heavy-volume loss drove shares below their 200-day moving average.
Water-heating products maker A.O. Smith (AOS) jumped 4% after a mixed earnings report. The light-volume gain lifted shares a bit more than 1% above a 71.91 cup-with-handle buy point.
Cirrus Logic (CRUS) notched a 3% gain. Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and Hawaiian Holdings (HA) jumped 2% each.
Overall, losses in the IBD 50 group were relatively mild, the worst being a 1% slip by China-based NetEase (NTES).
Oil prices traded down nearly 2% to $45.45 a barrel ahead of the Energy Information Administration's weekly inventories data, due out at 10:30 a.m. ET.

The chip industry's merger frenzy elevated Wednesday with two multibillion-dollar deals, one of which might result in a new chip-gear industry leader. Lam Research (LRCX) announced an agreement to buy KLA-Tencor (KLAC), and the combination might overtake Applied Materials (AMAT) in semiconductor equipment market share, says at least one analyst. The $10.6 billion merger was announced three hours before Western…
Stock futures pointed sharply higher, but were off their early highs ahead of Wednesday's start of trade, following some mixed early economic news and as markets rallied in Europe.

Dow futures steered up 118.7 points, and Nasdaq 100 futures traded 25.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures showed a 12.1-point gain. Small caps were positive and steady, with Russell 2000 futures holding a 4-point gain.

The stock market today opens with a two-day rally under its belt, with both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq ending higher in their trading ranges on Tuesday. Both indexes remain below their 50-day moving averages, although the Nasdaq is positioned for a possible test of that line this week.

Personal spending rose 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said, a welcome improvement from October's zero-gain showing and in line with economist expectations. Personal incomes rose 0.3%, a tad below October's 0.4% gain but better than views for a 0.2% advance.

Durable goods orders were flat for the month, sharply below October's (downwardly revised) 2.9% gain, but better than the 0.5% contraction projected by economist consensus. Minus transportation, orders dipped 0.1% vs. estimates for no change.
At 10 a.m. ET, the University of Michigan is scheduled to report its final consumer sentiment estimate for December and the Commerce Department gives its new home sales numbers for November.
The dollar was mixed early Wednesday, up vs. the euro, down against the yen. Bonds slipped, sending the 10-year yield up 2 basis points to 2.25%.

Crude prices moved higher, with the Brent crude and West Texas Intermediate benchmarks trading in tandem: both up 1.5% and just below $36.70 per barrel. Crude prices may see some effect from weekly U.S. inventories data from the Energy Information Administration, due out at 1030 a.m. ET. Metals and agricultural commodities were mixed.

Mining companies appeared poised to rally for another day, with BHP Billiton (BBL) up 6%, and Rio Tinto (RIO), Freeport McMoran (FCX) and Vale (VALE) jumping 5% each. The bounce in oil and mining issues tripped a rally on European markets, sending London's FTSE 100 up more than 2%, and the Cac-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX up nearly that much, in midday trade.

In U.S. stocks, Nike (NKE) vaulted nearly 3%, leading the Dow as well as the IBD 50 list in premarket action. The athletic wear maker reported late Tuesday its fiscal second-quarter earnings topped consensus forecasts. Revenue rose 4.1%, just shy of expectations. Gross margins increased more than forecast, to 45.6%, primarily due to higher selling prices. The stock has been testing support at its 10-week moving average, just below a flat base buy point of 133.62.

Devon Energy (DVN) spiked 11%. Devon has been highly active on the acquisitions front this month, paying $2.5 billion for assets in the Anadarko and Powder River basins, and sold its San Juan River holdings in New Mexico to BP (BP).

Celgene (CELG) mustered a 6% gain before the open. The drug maker announced the settlement of litigation vs. India's Natco Pharma and its U.S. partner, Arrow International, a subsidiary of Allergan (AGN), pertaining to patents for the oral cancer drug Revlimid. Celgene shares have been consolidating since July.

Micron Technology's  (MU) low fiscal Q1 guidance Thursday didn't hinder the stock Monday as shares gapped up on Wall Street and neared a month-high. For its Q1, Micron guided to $3.35 billion to $3.6 billion in revenue and 20 cents to 26 cents earnings per share ex items. Both measures fell short of the consensus, which saw 36 cents…

Texas Instruments (TXN) and Analog Devices (ADI) could grapple for Maxim Integrated Products (MXIM), which is rumored to be on the sales block amid heavy chip industry M&A action.Maxim stock was up 7% Wednesday afternoon on a report that Texas Instruments was looking to acquire the company. Reports last week had Analog Devices doing the same. Texas Instruments stock was down nearly 1% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, while Analog Devices stock was up a fraction.Bloomberg reported Wednesday that Texas Instruments is in talks to acquire Maxim. Maxim, which has an $11 billion market value, might not sell unless the company's receives a high premium, sources told Bloomberg.An $11 billion offer would actually be on the low end in terms of big chip industry deals this year. Broadcom (BRCM) is being acquired by Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago (AVGO) for a whopping $37 billion.That deal, announced in May, was the biggest pure-tech merger — until this month's announced $67 billion merger of Dell and EMC (EMC).In June, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR) for $16.7 billion.This month, Lam Research (LRCX) announced it plans to buy KLA-Tencor (KLAC) for $10.6 billion. That same day Western Digital (WDC) said it agreed to acquire SanDisk (SNDK) for $19 billion.Also this month, Microsemi (MSCC) leaped over the bid by Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) in a battle to acquire PMC-Sierra (PMCS), making a $2.4 billion offer.Chip M&A action has ramped amid an industry downturn with slowing growth, increasing costs and competition, and macroeconomic concerns, particularly in China, analysts say.Maxim makes sense for Analog Devices and Texas Instruments, analysts say, and both figure in on the M&A speculation.Texas Instruments CEO Kevin March, however, seemed doubtful of joining the M&A move, in comments during the company's recent Q2 earnings conference call with analysts."We already have what we believe is a significant scale advantage and we believe we're focused on the two best opportunities that are out there today, being analog and embedded processing," March told analysts. "So those two reasons aren't motivating us to think differently about M&A."MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing suggested in a research report that Texas Instruments might want to change its M&A tune."Assuming robust M&A activity, we think the potential exists for the creation of an analog competitor with comparable scale and cost leadership," he wrote. "Texas Instruments may need to respond pre-emptively and become acquisitive."Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter and on Facebook.

Inphi (IPHI) stock gapped up Wednesday on Wall Street after the chipmaker reported Q3 earnings that, for the eighth consecutive quarter, more than doubled year over year.And at least one analyst now sees Inphi as a potential M&A target.For its fiscal Q3 ended Sept. 30, Inphi reported 25 cents earnings per share ex items, up 108% year over year, and above the consensus which modeled 24 cents. Three months ago, Inphi guided to between 22 cents and 26 cents.Although Inphi has more than doubled its EPS in each of the last eight quarters, Q3 was the fourth in a row showing deceleration.Revenue of $62.4 million, up 72%, also beat the consensus of 12 analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, which saw $61.3 million. Inphi previously guided to $59 million to $63.6 million.In the current quarter, Inphi expects 25 cents to 27 cents EPS on $63.3 million to $65.3 million in sales. Sales would be up 17% at the midpoint while earnings would fall 13% at the midpoint vs. the year-earlier quarter.At least five analysts boosted their price targets on Inphi stock on Wednesday.Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan rates Inphi stock a buy and issued a price target of 31. He was "cautiously optimistic" on Inphi's return to business in China.Inphi CEO Ford Tamer said Tuesday that the chipmaker saw depressed Q2 mobile sales out of China reverse in Q3."We have seen a resumption of the China demand," Tamer told analysts during the Q3 earnings conference call. "We feel confident that Phase II of the China mobile infrastructure has resumed. So, based on the data we have today, we're seeing obviously orders flowing back in."Sundararajan sees "significant chances that Inphi could become a target of acquisition." M&A action within the chip industry hit a fever pitch this year with the multibillion-dollar acquisition deals selling SanDisk (SNDK) to Western Digital (WDC), KLA-Tencor (KLAC) to Lam Research (LRCX), Altera (ALTR) to Intel (INTC) and Broadcom (BCRM) to Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO).Inphi stock carries a high IBD Composite Rating of 97 out of a best-possible 99 in its Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group, putting it alongside other top-performing stocks like Integrated Device Technology (IDTI), ARM Holdings (ARMH), Monolithic Power Systems (MPWR) and Cavium (CAVM).Cavium stock, set to report its fiscal Q3 after the close Wednesday, was up nearly 1.5% in early trading. Integrated Device Technology stock, which beat forecasts in its Q2 report and announced an acquisition Tuesday, was up more than 3%.In morning trading on the stock market today, Inphi stock was up nearly 8%, trading near 30.Connect with Allison Gatlin on Twitter @IBD_AGatlin and on Facebook.

SanDisk (SNDK) got several downgrades Thursday following news of a megadeal with Western Digital (WDC), while eBay (EBAY) and Boeing (BA) both got new price targets and Visa (V) received new analyst coverage. Meanwhile, SolarWinds (SWI) was downgraded a day after its stock price popped 16% on the news that it's being acquired by investment firms Thoma Bravo and Silver…

The Dow Jones industrial average was in the driver's seat in early afternoon trading Wednesday, while tech stocks lagged, and the S&P 500 was mostly unchanged.The Dow rose 0.4%, helped by strength in United Technologies (UTX), Travelers (TRV), Caterpillar (CAT) and Boeing (BA) in the stock market today. Semiconductor ETFs trimmed early gains to close mildly higher Wednesday as industry mergers made headlines. The major indexes closed near session lows as investors digested a slew of corporate earnings.

Yahoo (YHOO) fell 5% as its 3Q financial results disappointed. Among stocks that brought cheer: EBay (EBAY), whose shares jumped 5% after hours as the e-commerce giant's quarterly profits easily cleared expectations. And chipmaker KLA-Tencor (KLAC), vaulted 19% after a Q3 beat and an announcement that Lam Research (LRCX) would buy the company in a $10.6 billion deal.
Also Wednesday, Western Digital (WDC) announced a $19 billion takeover of SanDisk (SNDK). SanDisk popped 2% on the news.
Despite reversing lower, semiconductors led sector-focused stock ETFs higher on the stock market today. Chip stocks are in comeback mode after getting mauled in the third quarter amid broad losses.
IShares PHLX SOXX Semiconductor (SOXX) finished 0.2% higher after advancing as much as 1.6% intraday. Market Vectors Semiconductor (SMH), which popped 1.4% in mid-day trade, closed 0.3% higher.
Intel (INTC) is the No. 1 stock holding in SOXX. It gained a fraction today but was far outpaced by the surge for KLA.
The ETF holds 30 U.S.-listed semiconductor stocks and caps weightings at 8% to provide broad-based exposure to a concentrated technology subindustry.
SanDisk is the sixth-largest holding in SOXX, at 5% portfolio weighting.
Semiconductor ETFs have rallied over the past three weeks but are trading well below their 52-week highs.
SOXX is 13% off its June high of 101.80. Month to date, SOXX is up 8%. It was gouged 11% in Q3.

The major indexes reversed into losses by the session close, with the Dow giving up 0.3% despite Boeing's (BA) earnings beat, and the S&P 500 giving up 0.6% amid solid results from General Motors (GM).

Carmaker General Motors handily beat estimates as China sales climbed 10%. The stock gapped up as much as 6% Wednesday, closing above its 200-day line for the first time since late June. Boeing rose 2% as it surpassed expectations for both earnings and revenue.
Japan led international ETFs higher Wednesday, while China ETFs slumped as much as 8%.
The largest gold ETF, SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), slipped nearly 1%, giving up its brief hold on the 200-day moving average.
Here's a look at how benchmark exchange-traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.

Apple (AAPL) chipmakers were up Wednesday ahead of the iPhone 6S launch Friday, but one analyst cautioned "we are past what coulda, woulda, shoulda been a potential inflection point" for semiconductor stocks. Both the iPhone 6S and 6S Plus have sold out of existing supplies online, ahead of the launch, which pretty much assures lines at retail stores Friday. Still,…

Applied Materials (AMAT) stock hit a nearly two-year low Friday after the No. 1 chip gear maker late Thursday reported Q3 revenue that missed Wall Street's forecast and offered lackluster Q4 guidance.CEO Gary Dickerson blamed unexpectedly floundering foundry sales for the Q3 revenue miss and lowered Q4 guidance. Thrifty customers have become adept at reusing their tools rather than ordering more, he said during the Q3 earnings conference call."So what we see in foundry is, in our fourth quarter, it's less than we anticipated," he said. "And we even saw, as we mentioned in my notes, that we had about an $8 million push-out of a foundry booking — or a cancellation, rather."In its fiscal Q3 ended July 26, Applied Materials reported $2.49 billion in revenue, up 10% vs. Q3 2014, but still short of analysts' forecast $2.54 billion. The company met Wall Street's earnings views of 33 cents per share ex items, up 18%.Orders Up SignificantlyThird-quarter orders were up 17%, led primarily by a $2 billion jump in silicon system orders, CFO Robert Halliday said on the call.Nand flash memory orders hit an all-time high, helped along by healthy demand for 3D chips, Halliday said. For 2015, Dickerson sees DRAM memory chip spending to grow 20% — despite a potential 10% drop in 2016 — as the mobile market continues to flourish.3D chips, used in 4K TVs, will have a long life in the semiconductor industry, Halliday said."You can't keep shrinking; electrons in a cell, you can't get any smaller. ... So they're going to go to 3D," he said. "So I think if anything, you've got a solid baseline of predictable spending that's pretty healthy in 3D Nand for a number of years."For Q4, the chipmaker forecast flat revenue but also said that it could drop as much as 7%. The company forecasts EPS minus items of 27 cents to 31 cents, which would be down 12% at the midpoint vs. Q3.Secular Or Cyclical Problem?Analysts latched onto the foundry dilemma. At least three lowered their price targets on Applied Materials stock.Cowen and Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri urged Applied Materials management "to shake things up with something bold." Applied Materials should be ready for a major industry shakeup should tool reuse become the norm, he wrote in a research report."Even as 3D Nand continues to upside, lingering confusion around whether or not there are secular changes underway in foundry/logic continue to hit AMAT," he wrote. "The time is now to shake things up."Arcuri recommended competitor LAM Research (LRCX) over Applied Materials and lowered his price target on Applied Materials to 24 from 25. He rated Applied stock outperform.Weston Twigg, a Pacific Crest Securities analyst, worried that the foundry "headwind" could continue for several quarters.But, he wrote in a report, "there's a lot to like with AMAT." He pointed to Applied's growing etch business as another order winner in Q3; he added that operations expenses were under control and that gross profit margins were improving.Twigg lowered his price target on Applied Materials stock to 23 from 27 and rated the stock overweight.Mahesh Sanganeria, an RBC Capital analyst, rated Applied Materials stock sector perform and dropped his price target to 16 from 19.Sanganeria sees Applied Materials being too optimistic heading into 2016."Management expects DRAM spending down 10% and Nand to remain at a high level, driven by continued 3D Nand investment," he wrote in a report. "In our opinion, memory spending will likely see a significant decline after three years of growth."JPMorgan analyst Harlan Sur lowered his price target on Applied Materials stock to 25 from 26. Based on the company's "impressive orders," Deutsche Bank analyst David Folkerts-Landau reiterated a buy rating on Applied Materials stock.In early afternoon trading in the stock market today, Applied Materials was down more than 3%, trading near 16.50.
Stocks jabbed higher at the open, then quickly turned mixed in rising volume Tuesday morning.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 ticked up 0.5% and 0.1%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.1%.
Volume rose in the stock market today, up 12% on the Nasdaq and the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.

Chemical maker DuPont (DD) dived more than 2% following mixed first-quarter results, weighing heavily on the Dow. Software giant SAP (SAP) popped 3% after its Q1 report, continuing its advance off a January low. Harley-Davidson (HOG) dived nearly 9% after reporting a mixed Q1, taking the worst early hit among S&P 500 stocks.

Chip equipment maker Lam Research (LRCX) spiked 10% at the bell. The Fremont, Calif.-based maker of wafer fabrication tools reported late Monday fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings that cleared the consensus estimate, and its Q4 revenue guidance was also above views. The gain put shares back above critical levels of support within a two-month consolidation.

Mylan (MYL) rumbled up 8% at the start of trade after Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA) bid $80 billion to acquire the Pennsylvania-based drugmaker. Teva's $82-per-share proposal projects $2 billion in annual cost savings and Teva said the deal would be more advantageous to Mylan than its effort to acquire Perrigo (PRGO).

Mylan last week said a combination with Teva was "without sound industrial logic or cultural fit" and that there was significant overlap between the two companies. Teva shares rose 2% at the starting bell. Tuesday's gain put Mylan 24% above a 59.70 flat base buy point.

Noah Holdings (NOAH) surged 3% to a new high. Semiconductor stocks jumped to the front Tuesday, posting some strong gains after quarterly earnings reports, amid a busy reporting schedule this week. Lam Research (LRCX) spiked 8%, jump-starting the right side of a volatile pattern.

Late Monday, Lam Research topped earnings views and guided forecasts higher. It earned $1.40 a share, excluding items, for the quarter ended March 29, up 11%, according to Thomson Reuters. Sales rose nearly 14% to $1.39 billion. The stock has a weak Composite Rating.
ARM Holdings (ARMH) gapped up to a 4% gain, also in powerful trade after the company beat sales expectations and profit met views.

The U.K.-based firm develops chips used in more than 95% of all smartphones. Chips used in server and enterprise networking markets, developed with partners including Qualcomm (QCOM) and Freescale Semiconductors (FSL), are one of its biggest growth opportunities.
The stock is forming a cup base with a 54.74 buy point.
Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) jumped 2% after it beat estimates for the first quarter.

The Israel-based semiconductor company earned 60 cents a share — adjusted for amortization costs and stock option expenses, up 500%. That beat estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 49% to $146.7 million, accelerating for a third straight quarter. It posted strong gains in its Ethernet market.

After the close, Broadcom (BRCM) reported a Q1 earnings gain of 94% to 64 cents a share, beating expectations. The company also gave a bullish forecast. In stocks, Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) pared its loss to 3% after missing views late Monday. After Monday's close, the drugmaker posted Q3 earnings that rose 10% to $2.52. On the upside, D.R. Horton (DHI) rallied 3% after beating views. Before the open, the homebuilder posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 64 cents a share, 2 cents above views. Sales came in at $3.09 billion vs. views of $3.04 billion. D.R. Horton closed on 10,576 homes during the quarter, up 23% from a year ago. The stock hit resistance at its 50-day moving average.

Stocks were still down hard, but have crawled off their lowest levels late Wednesday.The Nasdaq was off 1.6% and the S&P 500 lost 0.8%. They had been down as much as 1.9% and 1.1% respectively. The stock is on pace to snap a six-session win streak.Five Below (FIVE), Red Hat (RHT) and Verint Systems (VRNT) are a few notable companies reporting earnings after the close. All three were lower ahead of their results.

Worldwide sales of semiconductor capital equipment rose 18% to $37.5 billion in 2014, but not all regions and companies benefited from the robust increase. Taiwan remained the largest market for new chip gear for the third year in a row, with $9.41 billion in sales, or 25% of the total market, according to trade group SEMI. But its sales dipped…
SanDisk (SNDK) was upgraded Wednesday by an analyst upbeat about the supply/demand balance for flash-memory chips this year, as well as a new product launch, cost-cutting and other factors.
Goldman Sachs analyst Mark Delaney, in a research report Wednesday, upgraded SanDisk to conviction buy from neutral and boosted his price target to 106 from 100.
Delaney said demand for Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus are helping to drive Nand flash memory demand. Nand is the main type of flash memory.

Overall demand should pick up from a seasonally slow first quarter, he said. Applied Materials (AMAT), Tokyo Electron and Lam Research (LRCX) had lowered their Nand flash memory orders in the second half of 2014, he says.

The Milpitas, Calif.-based flash-memory chipmaker on March 3 launched an enterprise flash storage product designed for customers requiring large storage capacity and computing power for Big Data and hyperscale workloads.
The market for Big Data flash "memory was more than $11.3 billion last year and has seen double-digit growth over the past five years," research firm IDC reported in September.
"SanDisk's new all-flash array gives it access to a sizable growth market with high margins, and this could change the intermediate to longer-term debate on the stock," Delaney said.

SanDisk stock was up 5% in midday trading in the stock market today, near 84. SanDisk stock, though, is down 14% this year following a weak Q4 earnings report and weaker-than-expected Q1 guidance, and is down more than 20% from an all-time high of 108.77 on July 31.

For the current quarter, SanDisk forecast revenue of $1.4 billion to $1.45 billion, down 4% to 7.3%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters now forecast $1.47 billion, but before the earnings report they had forecast $1.56 billion.
For 2015, SanDisk forecast revenue of $6.5 billion to $6.8 billion, down 2% to 2.6%.

SanDisk CFO Judy Bruner said in the Q4 earnings conference call with analysts that "the key product areas where we expect revenue growth in 2015 are enterprise and embedded solutions. In total, we expect our revenue to experience a year-on-year decline in both the first and second quarters and return to year-on-year growth in the second half of 2015."
Delaney says SanDisk benefits from the weaker yen.

"Each 10% weakening of the yen adds about 200 basis points to SanDisk's gross margin," Delaney said. That, combined with cost reductions and a better product mix, is expected to improve SanDisk's gross profit margin by year's end, he said.

Intel (INTC) received several upgrades and price target hikes Wednesday, following a mixed Q1 earnings report late Tuesday that showed surging server sales and improvement in the Internet of Things, but sluggish demand for personal computers."We are upgrading Intel to outperform while increasing our price target to 40 from 38, as we believe that bearish PC sentiment is fully priced into shares," RBC Capital Markets analyst Doug Freedman said in a research report Wednesday."Our upgrade is about double-digit data center growth driving a 25% increase in cash flow over the next two years," Freedman wrote. "It is not about quarter-over-quarter changes in inventory and reported gross margins."Q1 revenue at Intel's data center group, which reflects sales of server chips, rose 19% vs. the year-earlier quarter to $3.7 billion. Internet of Things Group revenue rose 11% to $533 million.Analysts at Canaccord Genuity, Nomura, Pacific Crest Securities and Topeka Capital Markets boosted their price targets on Intel stock Wednesday, but Cowen & Co. lowered its price target.Santa Clara, Calif.-based Intel, the No. 1 chipmaker and long the dominant supplier of processor chips for PCs, reported Q1 earnings per share excluding items of 41 cents, up 8%. Revenue was flat at $12.8 billion, in line with Intel's lowered revenue forecast. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected EPS of 41 cents on $12.9 billion in revenue.The chipmaker's Q2 revenue forecast also fell below views. Intel forecast $12.7 billion to $13.7 billion in revenue, with the midpoint below the analyst model for $13.5 billion.Still, Intel stock was up 4.5% in afternoon trading in the stock market today, near 33. Intel stock is down 9% this year.Data Center, IoT HighlightedIntel CEO Brian Krzanich said in a conference call with analysts late Tuesday that management is "confident in its strategy to drive growth.""We're focused on innovating in our client business, improving mobile profitability and investing in and growing profitable adjacent markets," Krzanich said. "We are applying our process technology leadership, silicon integration expertise and the efficient use of shared intellectual property. This strategy is delivering results as evidenced by the growth we saw this quarter (Q1) in the Data Center, IoT and Nand (flash memory) segments."Canaccord Genuity analyst Matthew Ramsay, in a research report Wednesday, raised his target price to 39 from 38, noting "continued strong data center, IoT and Nand momentum.""We continue to believe Intel has strong core fundamentals driven by sustained foundry advantages and strong secular momentum supporting 15-plus percent Data Center Group and 20% IoT Group growth potential," Ramsay said. "While mobile losses remain heavy, we believe Intel's modem/system-on-chip technology is gradually closing the gap in a quickly thinning herd of competitors."Krzanich also said "challenging macroeconomic conditions and an appreciating U.S. dollar weighed on our business" in Q1 and that its newly formed Client Computing Group results "reflected weakness in desktop demand and the depletion of PC supply-chain inventories."Krzanich declined to speculate on "rumors" when asked by analysts about acquisition plans, referring to recent news reports that Intel has been in talks to buy programmable chipmaker Altera (ALTR). Altera stock was up 2.5% in afternoon trading Wednesday, near 43.Improving Profit MarginsPacific Crest Securities analyst Michael McConnell in a research report Wednesday boosted Intel's price target to 37 from 35 and maintained an overweight rating, saying Intel's strong data center group results "buoys its gross margin."Intel's closely watched gross profit margin was 60.5% in Q1, down from 65.4% in Q4 but up from 59.6% in the year-earlier quarter. Intel expects its gross profit to improve to 62% in Q2, "plus or minus a couple of percentage points," citing higher selling prices and lower production costs.FBR Capital Markets analyst Christopher Rolland in a research note Wednesday said Intel's full-year revenue guidance (flat vs. last year's $55.87 billion) "was slightly better than feared."He said "the massive reduction in 2015 capital expenditures was a positive highlight as the bears' argument against increasing capital intensity should subside."Intel said it would cut $1.3 billion from 2015 capital expenditures to $8.7 billion, plus or minus $500 million. Yet, shares of chip equipment makers Applied Materials (AMAT), KLA-Tencor (KLAC)and Lam Research (LRCX) were all up at least 1% in afternoon trading Wednesday.Summit Research Partners analyst Srini Sundararajan said in a research note Wednesday that while it may seem "counterintuitive," Intel's lower capital expenditures could actually work in the semiconductor equipment company's favor because "most spending is likely on higher margin, higher revenue-per-unit" products.Intel for the first time in Q1 combined results from its money-losing Mobile and Communications Group with its profitable PC Client Group by forming the new Client Computer Group, which now includes sales from PC microprocessors and chips for smartphones, tablets and other mobile devices. Client Computer Group sales fell 8% to $7.4 billion.Intel forecast full-year revenue as flat with last year's $55.87 billion, which is a touch higher than the current consensus for $55.65 billion. Gross profit is expected to be 61%, plus or minus a couple of percentage points.Cowen and Co. analyst Timothy Arcuri on Wednesday lowered his price target on Intel to 33 from 37 but reiterated a market perform rating."Intel's full-year guidance was not unexpected, but also requires 2015 to be the most second-half loaded year since the 2009 recovery — a factor which raises some eyebrows given ongoing questions around PC demand and mix shift to low-end given the U.S. dollar's strength," Arcuri said.RELATED:SanDisk Q1 Likely To Be In Line With Preannouncement.

Intel late Tuesday reported mixed Q1 earnings as sluggish demand for personal computers offset robust sales of server chips and for the Internet of Things. Revenue was flat at $12.8 billion, in…

But with gross profit margins strong, shares rose in after-hours trading Tuesday. The world's largest chipmaker earned 41 cents a share, up 8% vs. a year earlier. Revenue ws $12.78 bil, essentially unchanged vs. a year earlier. Wall Street had expected EPS…

Facebook (FB) and many semiconductor companies are heading into the Q4 earnings season with much higher expectations, according to upward EPS revisions. Thomson Reuters says Wall Street analysts now expect Facebook to earn 48 cents per share minus items in Q4, compared with 31…

The number of new highs dropped off sharply Thursday as the general market took a beating. But a couple of highly rated chip stocks bucked market weakness. Lam Research (LRCX) touched a record high in a volatile session after reporting quarterly results late Wednesday. It ended up 2.11, or 3%, to 70 in more than three times average trade. Intraday,…

The chip industry is expected to lead the tech sector to a comparatively strong Q2 performance as PCs rebound and mobile gadget sales remain strong. Tech's Q2 will start coming into focus on Tuesday, when Intel (INTC) and Yahoo (YHOO) get the earnings season into full gear by posting their results after the market close. Airline stocks have taken flight as oil prices continue to fall.
IBD's airline industry group ranked No. 31 out of 197 in Tuesday's edition, up from No. 111 just three weeks ago. This week, it's been one of IBD's 10 top-performing groups.
The latest breakout was discounter Southwest Airlines (LUV).

The stock's base was a six-week cup with handle with a 35.45 buy point. It had a bullish reversal off the bottom in heavy volume for the week ended Oct. 17. It closed at 36.43, up 1.12 for the day. Volume was moderately above average.

Southwest reported earnings on Oct. 23 of 55 cents a share, a 62% increase from a year ago. Quarterly sales increases have been in single digits for the past two years. But the company beat estimates on both earnings and sales.
The trucking industry, like airlines, has made a sizable advance. The industry group ranked No. 14, up from No. 26 three weeks ago.

Breaking out of a flat base Tuesday was J.B. Hunt (JBHT), which ships goods for companies that are usually under long-term contracts. The stock closed Tuesday at 82.01, up 1.96. It's carved a flat base over 14 weeks, with a 80.09 buy point. The base showed signs of accumulation, but the stock's Relative Price Strength Rating is less than stellar due to the stock's long sideways trend.

Hunt has been rallying since it reported earnings Oct. 14. Its EPS was 87 cents a share, a 16% increase from a year ago. Revenue gained 12%, about in line with quarterly growth over the past two years.
Lam Research (LRCX) broke out Friday, although volume was barely above average and has remained mediocre.
But it's still within buy range from a 77.45 buy point. It closed Tuesday at 79.34, up 0.20.
The base was built over five weeks, the minimum time for a proper flat base. Lam makes equipment for the semiconductor industry, which makes it a cyclical business.
The chip equipment industry group ranked No. 42. Lam reported EPS Oct. 22 of 96 cents, up 19% from a year ago. Sales rose 14%.

A strong showing for the stock market Tuesday fueled a fresh batch of new highs. A screen run early in Tuesday's session yielded just 18 names — but by the close, the list had more than doubled.

In the health care space, Shire (SHPG) rose 2.24 to 258.91. It closed just above a 258.65 buy point of a late-stage base. Late Monday, the drugmaker said the Food and Drug Administration would give priority for Vyvanse, an ADHD drug that shows promise for treating binge eating.

Chip-equipment maker Lam Research (LRCX) cleared a flat-base buy point of 73.02. Shares rose 1.96 to 74.09 after Nomura Securities made positive comments. Last month, the company declared a quarterly dividend of 18 cents a share, giving it an annual yield of 1%.

Michaels (MIK) erased early gains, falling 0.10 to 17.91. It cleared an IPO base last week with a buy point of 17.38. The arts-and-crafts retailer, which also runs the Aaron Brothers chain, has come back to life after a lackluster IPO in June at 17. Shares gapped up 9% on Aug. 27 after the company reported second-quarter earnings and revenue above expectations.

Bain Capital and Blackstone Group (BX) took the arts-and-crafts retailer private in 2006 for $6 billion. Michaels filed to go public two years ago, but the IPO was delayed after its CEO resigned after a stroke.

Interactive Brokers Group (IBKR) added 0.05 to 25.16 after a base breakout last week over 24.35. Earlier this month, the company reported performance metrics for August. Customer equity rose 40% from a year ago to $55.7 billion. Customer accounts rose 17% to 269,000.
Specialty retailer Finish Line (FINL) stayed in rally mode ahead of its earnings report later this month. Shares picked up 0.14 to 31.51.

In the Aerospace/Defense group, the Brazil-based Embraer (ERJ) tried to clear a flat-base buy point of 40.47 but came up short. A 1% gain for the stock turned into a small loss by the close. Shares fell 0.08 to 38.89. The firm makes jets for commercial airlines and the military; it launched its private jet division in 2005. At the end of 2013, it held nearly 18% of the corporate jet market. Group peer Northrop Grumman (NOC) also hit a new high, rising 1.36 to 131.93.

The stock market today rallied for a fourth straight session, extending its rebound. A heavy batch of earnings reports helped lift the market Tuesday.
Better-than-expected quarterly results also helped Super Micro Computer (SMCI) and Yahoo (YHOO) to more gains after hours.

Server maker Super Micro reported fiscal Q1 sales of $443.3 million, up 43% from a year ago. Earnings came in at 46 cents a share, up from 22 cents a share in the year-ago period. Views were for profit of 38 cents a share on revenue of $418.02 million. Shares rallied 4% in extended trading.
Internet search portal Yahoo rose 3% after hours after reporting Q3 sales of $1.09 billion vs. views for $1.04 billion. Earnings jumped 53% to 52 cents a share, smashing views of 30 cents a share.

But VMware (VMW) slipped about 1% after hours despite beating views. The virtualization software provider reported earnings of 87 cents a share on sales of $1.52 million. Analysts had expected 83 cents on revenue of $1.5 billion.

In the regular session, the Nasdaq bolted 2.4% and the S&P 500 rallied 1.9%. The latter regained its 200-day moving average. Blue-chips underperformed on the day, as the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.3%. Volume surged on both major exchanges from Friday's pace.

Biogen Idec (BIIB), O'Reilly Automotive (ORLY), Polaris Industries (PII), Lam Research (LRCX), Skechers (SKX) and Yelp (YELP) are among some notable companies reporting earnings Wednesday. Data on September consumer prices will also be out Wednesday.The stock market today rallied for a fourth straight session, extending its rebound. The major stock indexes continued to push ahead Friday afternoon and have retraced the bulk of Thursday's losses.Chips, software, solar and biotech helped lift the Nasdaq to a 1.3% gain. Its stock is now 24% past a 42.59 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Stocks edged lower Tuesday but the major indexes kept holding tightly to their recent gains. The Nasdaq eased 0.1% and the S&P 500 was down only a fraction. Volume rose modestly across the board. It was the Nasdaq's third straight decline, but the brief descent has been mild. The composite hasn't lost more than 0.1% each of the past three…
Stocks fell moderately Tuesday but traded in a tight range and held near highs with less than two hours remaining in the session.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial each lost 0.1% while the S&P 500 fell fractionally. Volume on the NYSE was tracking 6% higher than Monday. Nasdaq volume fell 2%.

In the stock market today, several chip stocks outperformed in heavy volume. Skyworks Solutions (SWKS), a Leaderboard stock at Investors.com, jumped 6% after the company issued bullish earnings and sales guidance for the current quarter. The company said it expects to continue to benefit from growing interest in Web-connected appliances and devices, otherwise known as the Internet of Things.
Meanwhile, chip-equipment makers Applied Materials (AMAT), and Lam Research (LRCX) were beneficiaries of positive comments by Jefferies.
Applied Materials extended gains after a recent cup-with-handle breakout over 20.51. Shares rose 4%. The stock is near the high end of a buy range, 4% above the buy point.
Lam Research added 3%. The stock extended 9% above a flat-base buy point of 59.04.

Meanwhile, Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up for the second time in six trading sessions. Shares surged 9% after Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) raised its bid for the company to $7.7 billion, or $55 a share. The new offer tops an earlier bid from Tyson Foods (TSN) that valued Hillshire at $50 a share.

Elsewhere, automakers didn't move much despite reporting better-than-expected U.S. new-car sales in May. Sales at Nissan (NSANY) jumped 18.8% from a year ago; Toyota (TM) rose 17%; Chrysler, owned by Fiat, climbed 16.7% and General Motors (GM) increased 12.6% from a year ago.

Ford (F) showed the slowest growth, up just 3%. Dillard's (DDS) ramped up 14.40, or 15%, to 111.00 in huge turnover. The stock hit an all-time high and closed 18% past a 94.38 buy point from a…
Chip gear maker Applied Materials (AMAT) is scheduled to report its fiscal second-quarter earnings after the market close Thursday.

The consensus estimate, among analysts polled by Thomson Reuters, is for revenue of $2.35 billion. That would be up 20% from the same quarter a year ago and its third quarter in a row of double-digit gains.
That was preceded by eight quarters in a row of double-digit declines.
The consensus on earnings per share minus items is 28 cents, up 75% from the year-ago quarter.

Applied Materials is a leading manufacturer of equipment to make semiconductors, flat panel displays and solar photovoltaic products. Applied Materials says its technologies have made smartphones, flat screen TVs and solar panels more affordable and accessible to consumers and businesses worldwide.
The stock of rival semiconductor equipment supplier Lam Research (LRCX) rose 12% the morning after it posted quarterly earnings that topped estimates on April 23.
Applied Materials stock dipped 0.8% to 18.95 on Wednesday.
In a report this week, RBC Capital Markets maintained a sector perform, or hold rating, on Applied Materials, with a price target of 18.
D.A. Davidson has a buy rating on Applied Materials with a price target of 21.

"Applied Material's dominant market position, emerging industry technology inflections and healthy spending from key customers position the company extremely well to post meaningful earnings growth and cash generation over the next year," Davidson analyst Thomson Diffely wrote.

On Tuesday, Applied Materials announced it scheduled a special meeting of its stockholders for June 23 to vote on the company's previously announced merger with Tokyo Electron. The two companies control about 40% of the wafer fabrication equipment market. Applied and Tokyo Electron are the Nos. 1 and 3 players in the semiconductor equipment market. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were off 0.1% as the S&P 500 fell by even less.
It was the third down day for the Nasdaq after a sharp rally. Each of the three days, the index has finished well off its lows of the day.

Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) rose rose 6% in brisk trade. It hit its highest level since December 2000. The company raised earnings and sales guidance and said it continues to benefit from the growing interest in Web-connected appliances, also known as the Internet of Things.

Hillshire Brands (HSH) gapped up again and finished nearly 10% higher after Pilgrim's Pride (PPC) raised its bid for the stock. The stock is up 55% since Pilgrim's Pride and Tyson Foods (TSN) started a bidding war for the company.

Chip stocks were generally higher, among them Applied Materials (AMAT), which was 4% higher. Jefferies started coverage with a buy rating. The stock broke out of a cup-with-handle base.

The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%.
Volume was soft, down 12% on the Nasdaq and 17% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday.

The stock market today has an eye on the Federal Open Market Committee, which is meeting in Washington but not expected to generate any news until the policy announcement scheduled for 2 p.m. on Wednesday.

Other economic news began with home prices, which were effectively flat in May, according to a 4.9 reading for the Case Shiller 20-City Home Price Index. Economists had expected a reading of 5.6. April's number was revised a notch higher, to 5.

The Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index also fell, dropping to 90.9 in July, down from June's 101.4 tally, which was revised lower to 99.8. Economist consensus projected a very slight dip, to 99.6, for July.

A more positive note from researcher Markit reported the services sector of the economy improved in July. The preliminary estimate for its PMI index rose to 55.2, up from a 54.8 reading in June. Consensus had looked for a no-change number of 54.8.
In stocks, reactions were generally positive as quarterly reports rolled out from a broad range of companies.

Ford (F) and heavy truck maker Paccar (PCAR) climbed nearly 2% each. GrubHub (GRUB) jumped 3% after its Q2 report. Norway's state-owned oil producer Statoil (STO) jumped more than 2% on its second-quarter results.

Baidu (BIDU) posted the news-leading decline, with shares diving 14% after the company reported a Q2 earnings miss late Monday. The drop put shares down 17% so far for the week, and far below critical levels of support.

Cummins (CMI) powered up almost 4% after the diesel engine maker easily beat analysts' second-quarter sales and earnings projections. Management held to its prior revenue guidance for the year, which is consistent with consensus views. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since June last year.

United Parcel Service (UPS) swept up nearly 4% as its earnings beat consensus estimates. Revenue stopped short of expectations, but management backed its prior EPS range of $5.05 to $5.30 for the year, and said it would come in near the top of that range. The stock has been crawling along the bottom of a flat consolidation and fighting to retake 10-week support since January.
The IBD 50 list opened the session evenly split — half up, half down at the start of trade.
Horizon Pharma (HZNP) and Blackhawk Network (HAWK) led the group, up more than 2% each. United Therapeutics (UTHR) grabbed the low post, dropping almost 4% after a mixed second-quarter report.

JetBlue Airways (JBLU) slipped nearly 4% after 132% EPS growth met Q2 expectations, but an 8% revenue gain stopped short of consensus estimates. The stock narrowed its gain to 2% above a 21.70 buy point following a low volume breakout.Stocks were tightly mixed at Tuesday's open, with earnings reports driving much of the early action.The Nasdaq, hamstrung by Baidu's (BIDU) 14% decline, fought with a fractional loss. Stocks reversed sharply in early trade Thursday, with premarket gains evaporating after Russia's defense minister announced a fresh round of military exercises on the Ukraine border.
The Nasdaq jumped 1.2% at the open, then dropped 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 also shed early gains and were down 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively.
Volume was strong, up 48% on the Nasdaq and 13% higher on the NYSE, compared with early Wednesday's activity.
The stock market today. The company sweetened the pot, increasing its share buyback program and its dividend and announcing a 7-for-1 stock split, to take effect June 9.

Caterpillar (CAT) rumbled up more than 3%. The global mining, construction and diesel power plant maker said mining equipment sales continued lower. Construction machine sales improved, as did sales in the U.S., while sales in China rose 30% for the quarter vs. a year ago.
The equipment maker is extended from a breakout from a cup-with-handle base.

Lam Research (LRCX) led the Nasdaq 100 with an 11% gain in powerful trade. The maker of chip production equipment reported after Wednesday's close its fiscal third-quarter earning swept up 186%, well above projections. Revenue growth of 39% narrowly topped forecasts. Management hoisted Q4 earnings and revenue guidance above consensus estimates.
Thursday's pop sent shares past resistance near 57, to 3% below their April 3 high.

Leading stocks posted their strongest start of the week, then quickly reversing course. All but a handful of the IBD 50 members advanced in opening trade. Within the first half-hour, four in five stocks had reversed into losses.
Facebook (FB) opened at the top of the list, but quickly turned a 4% gain into a fractional loss.
Cavium (CAVM) pulsed up 3% at the open, then backed into a 1% decline.

At the bottom of the list, Chicago Bridge & Iron (CBI) fell 5% after reporting below-forecast first-quarter results late Wednesday. Midcap stock mutual funds, like their small-cap cousins, have lagged large-cap funds and the S&P 500 this year, but midcaps remain close behind small caps' stellar performance in the past 15 years. Look what a $10,000 investment on Sept. 30, 1999, would do in each. Investors holding the average midcap stock fund would have $36,323 as of Oct. 20 this…
Even though many top-rated stocks scored new highs Tuesday, many of them reversed lower.

Albemarle (ALB) dropped 2.59, or nearly 4%, to 70.03 in a wild session on news that it's buying rival Rockwood Holdings (ROC) in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $6.2 billion. Albemarle expects about $100 million in cost savings by 2016.
Intraday, shares of Albemarle rallied as much as 5% and fell nearly 6%. Albemarle closed a tad below its 50-day line. Rockwood Holdings gapped up and surged 7.44, or 10%, to 83.14.

BitAuto (BITA) lost 1.39, or nearly 3%, to 51.80 after turning tail from an all-time high. It snapped a four-session win streak but closed 10% past a 47.03 buy point. Volume was above average but not super heavy. The stock fell 7% below that entry point July 10 intraday but also reversed higher that day.

The company provides auto-related Internet content and marketing services in China. It has delivered triple-digit profit growth in three of the past four quarters. Sales grew 40% to 47% in the latest four periods.

Gentherm (THRM) slipped 57 cents to 47.24 in soft trade. All down days since June 23 have been in below-average volume. It's still 7% past a 44.09 buy point from a rare ascending base. It has been on a tear since breaking out from a cup-with-handle pattern in October. Tuesday marked its first loss in three sessions for the maker of automotive climate-controlled seats.
On Tuesday, the Commerce Department reported a disappointing 0.2% increase in June retail sales. Auto sales, which were surprisingly weak, fell 0.3%.
Lam Research (LRCX) gave up 48 cents to 71.15 in slightly above-average trade. It appears to be cooling off after rising for nine straight weeks.
The stock closed nearly 21% past a 59.04 buy point from a flat base. Lam passed the buy point May 19 in lackluster trade. In most cases, investors should take profits once they amount to 20% to 25%.
The chip equipment maker's earnings growth accelerated for three straight quarters, with the last two in triple digits. Sales growth has picked up for two straight periods.

Dividends have been the consistent source of income for investors seeking regular returns during both bull and bear markets. According to a study, dividends accounted for an average 52% of the total returns over the past seven decades.This is especially true as these stocks offer the best of both these worlds — safety in the form of payouts and stability in the form of mature companies that are less volatile to large swings in stock prices. The companies that offer dividends generally act as a hedge against economic uncertainty and provide downside protection by offering outsized payouts or sizable yields on a regular basis (see: all the Large Cap ETFs here).Q2 Dividends Payout Hits Record Overall, the S&P 500 companies declared a record $124 billion in dividend payouts during the second quarter, up 11% from $112 billion in the year-ago quarter. About 89 firms hiked their payouts versus 67 firms a year ago, while 332 have maintained their dividends versus 347 in the same period last year. Notably, 43 companies have retained the ‘aristocrat’ status of 25 years of consecutive dividend raises. This is primarily thanks to a strong economy, solid earnings, historic tax cuts and results from the second round of Federal Reserve stress tests.Among the special attractions were Citrix Systems (CTXS  -  Free Report), which declared a dividend for the first time with a payout of 35 cents, and Dr Pepper Snapple , which announced a special dividend of $103.75 due to merger activity. Lam Research (LRCX  -  Free Report), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE  -  Free Report), Wynn Resorts (WYNN  -  Free Report), Ralph Lauren (RL  -  Free Report) and Starbucks (SBUX  -  Free Report) were among the firms that hiked dividend payouts (read: 4 Dividend Growth ETFs to Watch as Global Dividends Top).The trend is expected to continue in the coming months as most large companies have huge cash piles on their balance sheet and are in a position to increase payouts to shareholders. Additionally, the new tax law encourages the companies to bring their overseas cash back home at much more reduced rates and distribute parts of it to their shareholders. Per Bloomberg, an additional 75 companies will boost dividend payouts this quarter.Investors should also note that a company which consistently increases its dividend has stronger fundamentals, suggesting rising cash flows, good liquidity and a strong balance sheet.How to PlayGiven this, investors could tap growing dividends in the form of ETFs. Below, we have highlighted five popular dividend ETFs that offer excellent dividend growth potential, any of which could be a solid pick for investor in the long term: Vanguard Dividend Appreciation ETF (VIG  -  Free Report)This is the largest and most popular ETF in the dividend space with AUM of $27.8 billion and average daily volume of about 797,000 shares. The fund follows the NASDAQ US Dividend Achievers Select Index, which is composed of high quality stocks that have a record of raising dividend every year. It holds 182 securities in the basket, with none accounting for more than 4.3% share. The fund charges 8 bps in annual fees and has a Zacks ETF Rank #3 (Hold) with a Medium risk outlook (read: Tariff Threats Become Reality, Add 6 ETFs to Your Arsenal).iShares Select Dividend ETF (DVY  -  Free Report)This fund provides exposure to the high dividend-paying U.S. equities with a 5-year history of dividend growth. It follows the Dow Jones U.S. Select Dividend Index and holds 99 securities in its basket with each accounting for less than 2.4% of assets. The ETF has AUM of $17.1 billion and average daily volume of more than 716,000 shares. It charges 39 bps in fees per year from investors and has a Zacks ETF Rank #3 with a Medium risk outlook.SPDR S&P Dividend ETF (SDY  -  Free Report) With AUM of $15.6 billion and average daily volume of 548,000 shares, this fund provides a well-diversified exposure to 112 U.S. stocks that have been consistently increasing their dividends every year for at least 20 years. This can be done by tracking the S&P High Yield Dividend Aristocrats Index. Each firm accounts for less than 2.3% of assets. The fund charges 35 bps in fees and has a Zacks ETF Rank #3 with a Medium risk outlook.Schwab U.S. Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD  -  Free Report)With AUM of $7.5 billion, this product offers exposure to the 105 high-dividend yielding U.S. companies that have a record of consistent dividend payments supported by fundamental strength based on financial ratios and ample liquidity. This can be easily done by tracking the Dow Jones U.S. Dividend 100 Index. The fund is well spread across components, with none holding more than 4.81% of assets. It charges 7 bps in annual fees and trades in solid volume of more than 1 million shares a day. It has a Zacks ETF Rank #2 (Buy) with a Medium risk outlook.iShares Core Dividend Growth ETF (DGRO  -  Free Report)This fund provides exposure to companies having a history of consistently growing dividends by tracking the Morningstar US Dividend Growth Index. It holds 455 stocks in its basket with each accounting for less than 3% share. The fund has accumulated $3.7 billion in its asset base and trades in solid volumes of about 684,000 shares. It charges 8 bps in fess per year and has a Zacks ETF Rank #3 with a Medium risk outlook.Want key ETF info delivered straight to your inbox? The Trump administration announced plans today for a stronger security review process of foreign investors acquiring American technologies that would rely on existing laws, taking a step back from previous gestures indicating it would specifically block Chinese investments.This move is perceived as more economically friendly to global investors who were concerned the U.S. Treasury was about to create a virtual blockade of firms with at least 25 percent Chinese ownership from buying U.S. companies with "industrially significant technology."“Such legislation will provide additional tools to combat the predatory investment practices that threaten our critical technology leadership, national security, and future economic prosperity,” Trump said in a statement.Instead of creating new executive powers, the Treasury Department recommended that Trump use the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS), a 1980s law which already gives the executive branch the power to review foreign investments seen as a national security risk.Loose WH Lips Sink ChipsPart of the volatility for global stock markets the past few months has been due to the unpredictable rhetoric from the Administration. With no less than five voices besides Trump's -- including Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross, US Trade liaison Robert Lighthizer and economic advisors Larry Kudlow and Peter Navarro -- all speaking to the media, many apparently "official" statements are later retracted or modified.In the end, any meaningful action on the Chinese threat to US intellectual property is probably a good thing. But it's the short-term uncertainty about how it evolves that has both investors and technology companies on edge.Caught in the middle of the White House "America First" agenda are a number of big US companies who complain that the tariffs penalize them for their globe-spanning supply chains. And the Semiconductor industry may be the most vulnerable right now.Global supply chains for Semiconductor manufacturing and equipment are probably some of the most complicated. Tariffs will definitely throw a wrench in the works.Chips are often designed and produced in the US, sent to China for packaging or testing and then returned back to the States. The chips would now be subject to tariffs on the return trip.Earlier this month, a spokesman for the Semiconductor Industry Association made their views clear..."Tariffs on semiconductors would harm, not help, U.S. semiconductor companies, their workers, and American consumers."In the video that accompanies this article, I go over the last few week's of "trade battle" rhetoric that have led to a 9% sell-off in the Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (SOX), and individual declines (from their June peaks) in these 5 popular investments...Lam Research (LRCX  -  Free Report): -17%Applied Materials (AMAT  -  Free Report): -14%These first 2 companies are wafer fabrication equipment (WFE) makers for the actual chip makers like Intel, Samsung, Micron and even NVIDIA.Micron (MU  -  Free Report): -13.5%NVIDIA (NVDA  -  Free Report): -11%Alibaba (BABA  -  Free Report): -11.5%Wait -- Alibaba isn't a chip stock. Why did I include them?Because I can't believe this "Amazon of China" is a victim in this trade war. I explain in the video with my thesis on why you buy BABA as the premier gateway to the world's largest middle class.The Threat of "Made in China 2025"I also explain the motives of the Trump administration and what threat(s) in particular they are combating. This excerpt from a June 15 Wall Street Journal article gives some good background...White House officials said the goal of the tariff fight is to protect high-tech U.S. companies from pressure they face in China to transfer their technology to Chinese partners. Tariffs are necessary, the officials say, to force Beijing to change the way it does business."We're going to stop, we hope, their transfer of technology -- their forced transfer of technology," U.S. Trade Representative Robert Lighthizer said on Fox Business Network.What is "Made in China 2025?" It's their long-term strategic technology plan, issued by Chinese Premier Li Keqiang and his cabinet in May 2015, to comprehensively upgrade Chinese industry.The goals include increasing the domestic content of core materials to 40% by 2020 and 70% by 2025. The plan clearly focuses on high-tech fields including the pharmaceutical and semiconductor industries to which China has largely depended on US and European companies for advanced technology.The Council on Foreign Relations has said it believes the plan is a "real existential threat to U.S. technological leadership."And so it was no surprise when, on June 15, the Trump administration unveiled a lengthy tariff list mainly focused on the products included in the Made in 2025 plan, including IT and robotics related products.The War to Protect WFE -- And Its Costs Intel, Samsung, Micron and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing (TSM) have always been big customers for WFE. “But Chinese chip makers are starting to write some large checks as well," according to Dan Gallagher of the Wall Street Journal.Applied Materials CFO Dan Durn in his company's quarterly earnings call last month confirmed this sentiment from their business..."China is emerging as a spender. Their strategic intent is clear, and the financial resources they have are clear.“But as Dan Gallagher wrote in his June 25 article Chip-Equipment Makers in Crosshairs of Trade War...“Wars are generally good news for arms dealers. In the burgeoning trade war with China, the semiconductor-equipment industry may turn out to be a notable exception.“To be sure, China isn't the only driver of growth for the chip-equipment sector. Strong spending in memory and process-node upgrades at the major chip makers are also fueling increased spending on equipment. But Krish Sankar of Cowen & Co. estimates that China accounted for about 14% of trailing 12-month revenue, on average, for the eight semiconductor-tool companies he covers."That means the loss of future sales could be significantly more. War is hell.”While I have believed that we are in the midst of a Technology Super Cycle (email Ultimate@Zacks.com to get a free copy of my December 11, 2017 special report) driven by exponential data and memory demands, exponential mobile and connected/IoT device growth, artificial intelligence, and automation including ADAS vehicles, it looks like the "war on China" is throwing a big wrench in the works after all.But I still think it will set up terrific buying opportunities in all these companies as the pessimism peaks this summer. Here’s to a short battle with China instead of an all-out war.Disclosure: I own shares of NVDA, AMAT, MU, and BABA for the Zacks TAZR Trader portfolio.Kevin Cook is a Senior Stock Strategist for Zacks Investment Research where he runs the TAZR Trader service. Lam Research Corporation (LRCX  -  Free Report) could be a stock to avoid from a technical perspective, as the firm is seeing unfavorable trends on the moving average crossover front. Recently, the 50 Day Moving Average for LRCX broke out below the 200 Day Simple Moving Average, suggesting short-term bearishness.This has already started to take place, as the stock has moved lower by 15.4% in the past four weeks. And with the recent moving average crossover, investors have to think that more unfavorable trading is ahead for LRCX stock.If that wasn’t enough, Lam Research isn’t looking too great from an earnings estimate revision perspective either. It appears as though many analysts have been reducing their earnings expectations for the stock lately, which is usually not a good sign of things to come.Consider that in the last 30 days, 2 estimates have been reduced, while none has moved higher. Add this into a similar move lower in the consensus estimate, and there is plenty of reason to be bearish here.That is why we currently have a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) on this stock and are looking for it to underperform in the weeks ahead. So either avoid this stock or consider jumping ship until the estimates and technical factors turn around for LRCX.
